chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter helps you to access the Opics Portal using a web interface and introduces the portal home page. It also describes the conventions followed in the portal, such as date formats, currency formats, etc.

section.title: Accessing Opics Portal
section.para: Opics Portal requires the following browsers to launch the GUI:

listitem.para: Microsoft ® Internet Explorer 5.0 or later
Netscape Navigator ® 6.0 or later
Other web browsers that support JavaScript and cookies.
Go to the URL of Opics Portal in a web browser to open the Welcome page of the portal.
Click Login to My Account in the toolbar.
In the Login screen, specify the Username, the Password, and the Company associated with the user account.
Click on Login to access the portal home page.

note.para: To create a user account for the portal, refer to the Misys Portal Admin User Manual or contact the system administrator of your organization.

section.title: Portal Home Page
section.para: On successful login, the Home page of the portal appears. Although similar to the Welcome page, the Home page also contains:

listitem.para: Main Menu: (on the left side)
Provides a list of modules and features in Opics Portal. The items in this menu depend on which modules your account has permissions for.
Middle Section:
Displays items of recent news
Portlet:
An application running within the page, which is the Trade Calendar module. This module contains a calendar and the trade events, such as recent transactions, notifications, etc.

section.para:
The Opics Portal toolbar is the same on every page. On the left side, above the Main Menu is a link to the Home page. On the right side are three icons:
(Logout to exit the portal),
(System Features menu), and
(Help to view the online help).
All the modules for handling trades and accounting transactions are available on the Home page under the Main Menu and its corresponding sub menus.
Note: There may be additional toolbar specific to your site, though this is covered in this documentation.

section.title: Lists
section.para: Many functions display a page that lists relevant transactions. These list pages have many things in common:

listitem.para: You can enter search criteria in a group of fields at the top of the page and click on Search, to display only those records that match these criteria. These fields represent the most important fields in the transaction record, as do the columns in the table.
You can use the wildcard character, asterisk (*), anywhere in these fields.

On pages where the list might be very long – for example, if there are many transactions – the list is displayed only after you enter the search criteria and click Search. Enter an asterisk in any of the search fields to get the entire list.
If your company has entities defined in its profile, then a column and a search criterion field for Entity appear in addition to the columns and fields mentioned in the individual chapters.
You can click the heading in the column and then click on the triangular icon that appears in the heading to sort a column in a list in ascending or descending order.

In most lists you can click in a row to process the transaction shown in that row. Depending on the list, you can edit, view, or delete the transaction, or create an amendment request for it. In some lists you click anywhere in the row; in some lists you click the System ID column; while some lists have icons you can click to edit, view, or delete a transaction. Details are given in the sections for the individual functions.

section.title: Forms
section.para: Most functions display an input form, either immediately you click the function or after you click a row in a list displayed by the function. These forms have many things in common:

listitem.para: Near the top right of a form, a free-floating menu on a colored background appears. This menu is always on top as you scroll up and down the form and contains:
Show Form Summary.
Displays a menu of all section headings in the form. Click on a specific heading to go straight to that section.
Top:
Takes you back to the top of the form.

If a field has a
(magnifying glass) icon by it, you can click the icon to see a popup list of values. Click a value to insert it in the field. This is most often used for currency fields.

If a field has an
icon by it, you can click the icon to see a popup list of predefined phrases. Click a phrase to insert it in the field. You can then edit the field further. This is most often used for free-format fields such as Other Information fields.
In most date fields, you can enter the date in two ways:
Select the first option button to enter the required date. Click the field and select the date from the calendar.
Select the second option button to enter a length of time. Insert the number of days/weeks/months/years in the first field. Select from the dropdown list: Days, Weeks, Months or Years.

If a heading has an
icon by it, you can click the icon to expand the form, displaying a subsection that otherwise is not displayed. Click the
icon to close the subsection again.

section.para: This documentation describes each input form in detail, with a table describing each control (field, button, etc).

section.title: Date and Amount Conventions
section.para: When entering a date in a date field, you can enter it in the form:

listitem.para: DD/MM/YYYY or DDMMYY if your locale is France.
MM/DD/YYYY or MMDDYY if your locale is the USA.

section.para: For example, entering 180401 produces a display of 18/04/2001, which in a French locale corresponds to 18th April 2001.

When you enter an amount, the system automatically formats the value entered according to the currency selected. You can either enter the amount using the decimal and group delimiters of your locale (for example, respectively [,] and [space] for France, or [.] and [,] for Singapore), or directly as a series of digits.
For example, 123456.00 in a Singaporean locale produces a display of 123,456.00 if the currency involved is associated with 2 decimal places.
